Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: Collaborative Research: F: Discovering Context-Sensitive Impact in Complex Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Successfully tackling many urgent challenges in socio-economically critical domains (such as sustainability, public health, and biology) requires obtaining a deeper understanding of complex relationships and interactions among a diverse spectrum of entities in different contexts. In complex systems, (a) it is critical to discover how one object influences others within specific contexts, rather than seeking an overall measure of impact, and (b) the context-aware understanding of impact has the potential to transform the way people explore, search, and make decisions in complex systems. This project establishes the foundations of big data driven Context-Sensitive Impact Discovery (CSID) in complex systems and fills an important hole in big data driven decision making in many critical application domains, including epidemic preparedness, biological pathway analysis, climate, and resilient water/energy infrastructures. Thus, it enables applications and services with significant economic and health impact. The educational impacts of this project include the mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students, and the enhancement of graduate and undergraduate Computer Science curricula at both Arizona State University (ASU) and New Mexico State University (NMSU) through the incorporation of research challenges and outcomes into existing classes.

The technical goal of this project is to establish the theoretical, algorithmic, and computational foundations of big data driven context-sensitive impact discovery in complex systems. This project develops probabilistic and tensor-based models to capture context-sensitive impact from complex systems, often modeled as graphs, and designs efficient learning algorithms that can capture both the contexts and the impact scores among entities within these different contexts. The modeling of the context sensitive impact considers dynamic nature of relevant contexts and the diverse applications. This requires addressing several major challenges, including latent contexts of impact, heterogeneous networks of entities, dynamicity of impact in varying contexts, and high computational and I/O costs of context-sensitive impact discovery. Therefore, this project designs novel scalable probabilistic and tensor-based algorithms to capture and represent context-sensitive impact. These algorithms and the novel data platforms they are deployed in are efficient and scalable in terms of off-line and on-line running times and their space requirements. To achieve necessary scalabilities, the developed platforms employ novel multi-resolution data partitioning and resource allocation strategies and the research enables massive parallelism and efficient data access through new non-volatile memory based data management techniques.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award has supported research on establishing theoretical, algorithmic, and computational foundations of big data-driven Context-Sensitive Impact Discovery (CSID) in complex systems. With the support of this award, we have achieved the following major outcomes. 


Intellectual Merits. 

(1) Nine peer-reviewed and archived research articles were published in Computer Science (CS) venues. In these works, we introduced different variants of impact-finding problems, proposed novel models (probabilistic models, deep learning based models) and learning algorithms to solve the problems, and compared our new methods with dozens of baseline approaches using more than twenty different real datasets. These findings advance the literature of specific research topics including graph mining, graph search, time series mining, deep learning methods, and recommender systems. 

(2) Seven GitHub repositories for the source code used in our CS research articles were published. These GitHub repositories will enable other researchers to repeat what we have proposed and facilitate future improvement. 

(3) One peer-reviewed and archived article in the application area (Biology) was published. It examined the Integrative and Conjugative Element (ICE) and ICE-containing strains to understand whether these strains and their related bacterial adaptive immune system have impacting relationships. 

(4) Sixteen presentations were given in conferences and workshops as oral presentations or posters in CS and application venues. These presentations helped deliver our findings to a broader community. 


Broader Impacts.

The project has facilitated or resulted in the following educational, training, and outreach outcomes.

(1) This award has been instrumental in creating a campus-wide collaboration on big data analytics at NMSU. It has been effective in coalescing expertise, leading to the development of a new professional Master's degree in Computational Data Analytics, which was approved by the NM state in winter 2018.

(2) It involved training seven PhD students (five in CS and two in biology), three Master's students (one in CS&biology and two in plant and environmental sciences), and eight undergraduate students (seven in CS and one in plant and environmental sciences). Among these students, five are hispanic and three are female.

(3) This project is critical to the completion of two CS PhD dissertations.  

(4) A new course (CS 487/519 Applied Machine Learning) was introduced at the Computer Science department NMSU. This project is critical to the creation of the new course. 

(5) Collaborations with other disciplines (biology and plant and environmental sciences) have been strengthened. 

(6) Supported one REU Site and its renewal (https://www.cs.nmsu.edu/reu/).

(7) Two workshops (one at Arizona State University and one at NMSU) were hosted.

(8) All the significant outcomes from the project have been published at https://kddlab.nmsu.edu/project/nsf1633330/. 


Other Impacts.

New collaborations have emerged, leading to submissions of joint proposals.


Last Modified: 12/16/2020
Modified by: Huiping Cao

    Huiping Cao
